channel.title: vim on Sting's Note
channel.description: Recent content in vim on Sting's Note

item.title: Using python in ultisnips
item.description: This snipt uses python to convert Camal case to underline. It is an example to use python in ultisnips. t[1] gets content of $1. After the convertion, assign the result to snip.rv snippet gfk "gorm foreign key" $1ID uint \`gorm:"column:`!p name=re.sub(r"(\w)([A-Z])", r"\1_\2", t[1]).lower(); snip.rv = name`_id" json:"-"\` ${1:Model} $1 \`gorm:"foreignKey:$1ID" json:"`!p name=re.sub(r"(\w)([A-Z])", r"\1_\2", t[1]).lower(); snip.rv = name`"\` endsnippet

item.title: Use vim-projectionist to jump around in django projects
item.description: When working on django projects, I need to switching among django’s model, view, url, admin and serializers files. I used to use fzf.vim to jump around until I found vim-projectionist. With this plugin, you can create a “map” of your source code, with this map, you can just from for example, .c file to .h file. Create a .projections.json under your django file as follows: { "*/urls.py": { "type": "urls", "alternate": "{}/views.
